1C3B170B366E4272BB1034FD0FC8C88C.description: Reflect on own strategies for viewing, listening, reading, representing, speaking, and writing and set goals to improve the strategies used.

F5C2318C5EE54B258043167CAEC0958E.description: Ask questions such as “What do I already know? What can I already do? What strategies have I learned? What do I need to remember? What goals do I need to set for myself?”

E26BEEFE26CA46348A5832AE512806CF.description: Reflect on viewing, listening, reading, representing, speaking, and writing by explaining what is effective or what worked in a text.

9F38220542924AA9A219C185D0DEDA6C.description: Set and pursue personal goals to improve viewing, listening, reading, speaking, writing, and other representing tasks more effectively.

1A995100B5D849C4AB4FB33BB43C45D9.description: Reflect on own strategies for viewing, listening, reading, representing, speaking, and writing and set goals to improve the strategies used.

0235292DACEE454BAB93346B26A3B503.description: Ask questions such as “What do I already know? What can I already do? What strategies have I learned? What do I need to remember? What goals do I need to set for myself?”

C3FA66D981FC413DB6178266A437D3EF.description: Reflect on viewing, listening, reading, representing, speaking, and writing by explaining what is effective or what worked in a text.

5AB7BE6251FE4D6C8735C2A92934181F.description: Reflect on and assess own viewing, listening, reading, speaking, writing, and other representing experiences, the selected strategies employed (e.g., using class-generated criteria), and explore possible ways to improve.

39B5203394214400811B6541EE8F473F.description: Assess and Reflect (AR). Students will develop their abilities to assess and reflect on their own language skills, discuss the skills of effective viewers, listeners, readers, representers, speakers, and writers, and set goals for future improvement.

FCCDFD4152C24F3CA3AF6B1086A13782.description: Communicate and demonstrate understanding by creating original texts (e.g., poem, play, letter, journal entry) and by writing responses to texts, supporting judgements through references to both the text and prior knowledge.

4B9509DB8002402C8DD171A02E1E0252.description: Write summaries that contain the main ideas of the text or presentation and the most significant details.

95A04A6CCF6A44A1BE4613D4267AD0B0.description: Write procedures with clear directions and explanations.

5B9E4E8E42604BA58E0A0DFDBA5F1C35.description: Write information reports (3-5 paragraphs) that focus on a central question about an issue or situation, include facts and details, and draw from more than one source of information (e.g., speakers, books, newspapers, other sources).

DA511F06F33849B19BACA9F858EB7050.description: Write descriptions and narratives (3-5 paragraphs) that relate observations and recollections of an event or experience and use sensory details.

A37C916BB8C74172AC0E63E47274B70E.description: Create compositions with an introductory paragraph that establishes a central idea in key sentence(s), supporting paragraphs with simple facts, details, and explanations, and a concluding paragraph that summarizes the points.

2E083725EC7E4DF68D9E92F76CEE08EA.description: Write clear, coherent sentences and paragraphs that develop a central idea.

E5D87980D03343B983F64ED22CF25FA9.description: Understand and apply cues and conventions including pragmatic, textual, syntactical, semantic/lexical/morphological, graphophonic, and others to communicate meaning when writing.

46E0D49F42F94E599D1C65D41E8163F0.description: Select and use pertinent before, during, and after strategies to construct meaning when writing.

097AC1339D9D449A97D60771F5A2F534.description: Work through the stages of a writing process (e.g., pre-writing, drafting, revising successive versions).

5F0D5D46A59A46B0B5FDA88DD9278190.description: Use a writing process to produce descriptive, narrative, and expository compositions that focus on a central idea, have a logical order, explain point of view, and give reasons or evidence.

E96C938E237F49709CB736485C780C12.description: Make individual contributions to class discussion by expressing ideas, opinions, and feelings and interact with others to share ideas and opinions, ask for support, complete tasks, and explain concerns or problems

2B2FFB44EFB049128F01210603B3AF58.description: Recite brief poems (e.g., two or three stanzas), monologues, or dramatic dialogues using clear diction, tempo, volume, and phrasing.

360A4BEA27DF414299D51B78A4EE9D18.description: Deliver oral summaries that contain the main ideas and the most significant details of articles and books.

3DE3ECE4FC5641BBAA701A4502E0DF4B.description: Make informational presentations that frame a key question, include facts and details that help listeners to focus, and incorporate more than one source of information (e.g., interviews, books, newspaper articles, and television or radio reports).

E68D37CA1A2E488894AF74A6372124DF.description: Make narrative presentations that retell a traditional First Nations and Métis narrative.

45D1539BEC534C19999E22E05786760E.description: Make narrative presentations that relate ideas, observations, or recollections about an event or experience, provide a context that enables the listener to imagine the circumstances of the event or experience, and provide insight into why the selected event or experience is memorable.

713682F0CA3F4383925675B33F7E69E9.description: Present effective introductions and conclusions that guide the listener’s understanding of important ideas and evidence, use appropriate structure for conveying key information (e.g., cause and effect, similarity and difference), and use details, examples, anecdotes, or experiences to explain or clarify information.

FDC7CA32DCF84666BE4D1CAA0FD1CFCA.description: Understand and apply cues and conventions including pragmatic, textual, syntactical, semantic/lexical/morphological, graphophonic, and others to communicate meaning when speaking.

7FF20A5AB8164FAF82C9A922A57D7DF9.description: Select and use pertinent before, during, and after strategies to construct meaning when speaking.

6B88F4EC073D4B7C8D63914EC80FF2B8.description: Adapt language and presentation style to the purpose and needs of the audience, and guide the listener to understand important ideas by using proper phrasing, pitch, and modulation.

8338C4C6899545268ED937BDC1BEE8A6.description: Speak to present and express a range of ideas and information in formal and informal speaking situations (including giving oral explanations, delivering brief reports or speeches, demonstrating and describing procedures) for differing audiences and purposes.

00A7E6116C824758A015154BD48CA4BC.description: Experiment with different ways of representing ideas and sharing them with others (e.g., drama, mime, tableau, dance, music, models, painting).

4A213079D97145CA8582D5169135E3E0.description: Use visual aids (e.g., pictograms, graphs, charts, tables, diagrams, maps, illustrations, movement) to enhance spoken or written products.

E5E68272D4C847C7B030E04FBA916871.description: Express relevant opinions about experiences (e.g., an incident) through a variety of representations (e.g., multimedia presentation, role play).

BA20727A6E22432A82EA24A52588E08B.description: Organize information and ideas in visual and multimedia texts that are clear, meaningful, logical, and illustrative of the topic and are properly labelled and captioned.

F6E5913AC7504D6F96B20F455E41781F.description: Understand and apply cues and conventions including pragmatic, textual, syntactical, semantic/lexical/morphological, graphophonic, and others to communicate meaning when using other forms of representing.

78796D8BAF084C78AD93DC0AC3C67939.description: Select and use pertinent before, during, and after strategies to communicate meaning when using other forms of representing.

5184B660B91543DF959D22E0401FEA9B.description: Use a variety of visuals (e.g., chart, diagram) to communicate essential information when making an oral presentation.

DDD59E07268E423FA7964C24381EF22F.description: Create a variety of clear representations that communicate straightforward ideas and information relevant to the topic and purpose, including short, illustrated reports, dramatizations, posters, and other visuals such as displays and drawings

46EC7AFA680B4BFFAC107DD2D231D1D8.description: Use inquiry to explore authentic problems, questions, and issues associated with identity, community, and social responsibility including: asking general and specific inquiry questions on topics using predetermined categories. recording, selecting, and sharing relevant personal knowledge and understanding of a topic or questions and considering purpose for individual and group inquiry or research, selecting and using a plan for gathering ideas and information, assessing the usefulness, authenticity, and reliability of information for inquiry or research needs using preestablished criteria, using a variety of tools (including indices, maps, atlases, charts, electronic sources) and resources to access ideas and information, organizing ideas and information in logical sequences, making notes and citing authors and titles of sources alphabetically, examining collected information to identify categories or aspects of a topic that need more research, sharing findings and conclusions in a clear visual, oral, and written format and using the language of inquiry (e.g., “I want to know if .…”, ”I wonder about ….”).

389EEAB0C3D44F92A5CC0BFE952081A1.description: Compose and communicate findings and conclusions about problems, questions, or issues in a clear visual, oral, and written format.

3711F764F67547AC8DB330B6CF2326E1.description: Create spoken, written, and other representations that include: a specific message, a coherent organization of ideas, ideas and information which are clear and complete and appropriate use of language and conventions.

D72B629CF55244459A71C838F9FD054A.description: Compose and create a range of visual, multimedia, oral, and written texts that explore: identity (e.g., Expressing Myself), community (e.g., Celebrating and Honouring Others) and social responsibility (e.g., Within My Circle) through personal experiences and inquiry.

8C3D12404BED40D4A4E496B545E02FD0.description: Compose and Create (CC). Students will develop their abilities to speak, write, and use other forms of representations to explore and present thoughts, feelings, and experiences in a variety of forms for a variety of purposes and audiences.

1EEA32DAAF77409583E6BBAD9D503FCD.description: Read grade-appropriate texts silently (e.g., 20 minutes; 135-185 wcpm) and orally (with fluency, accuracy, pacing, intonation, and expression; 100-140 wcpm), adjusting reading rates to the complexity of the materials and the purpose for reading.

721B9EAFB5A04187BFE68C1AC7392478.description: Support opinions and conclusions about what is read.

5499552D45674639AA4287DDED4AACA7.description: Read and use grade four reference texts (e.g., dictionary, encyclopedia, how-to, explanations, biography) for inquiry and to identify main ideas, details, opinions, and reasons.

36C8029367BD429D920BE9C3BD2DB27E.description: Follow multi-step written instructions and procedures in basic technical or how-to manuals (e.g., how to play a video game).

2FC8BE51CC764BD18D5F354DC88B7EB3.description: Compare information on the same topic after reading several passages or articles.

04F45FF677C54741B6350CB133A5309F.description: Read for information in content area resources and reference materials and recognize the variety of expository text structures including compare-contrast, problem-solution, cause and effect, time sequence, and description.

134F3394468248868012A8BF10AEBC6E.description: Read and summarize narrative texts including First Nations and Métis narratives and identify characters’ traits, characters’ changes over time, and the theme.

7736FD5169D542D081C597F7AF1B41E6.description: Understand and apply cues and conventions including pragmatic, textual, syntactical, semantic/lexical/morphological, graphophonic, and others to construct and confirm meaning when reading.

41A3E2447F0C4EE2B5C5A19A212F6203.description: Select and use pertinent before, during, and after strategies to construct meaning when reading.

585391B13BAA4B2697AFEA05A036570A.description: Recognize and explain the author’s ideas, explicit and implicit message, and techniques (e.g., use of figurative language).

F4BF90994E174EE19524AD3074E59BF3.description: Read for various purposes and demonstrate comprehension of gradeappropriate fiction (including stories and novels), scripts, poetry, and non-fiction (including magazines, reports, instructions, and procedures) from various cultures including First Nations and Métis and countries (including Canada).

83EEE1AAEB4645FE94D82CEE54DAC79C.description: Draw conclusions supported by ideas presented.

6D4B682ED65D41B589721A57E53F05F3.description: Follow multi-step directions and instructions independently.

AE26CAB7A5E242F19F275A46550885BC.description: Summarize and paraphrase major ideas and supporting evidence presented in spoken messages and formal presentations.

35178791F76A4CB6935207C9CDF1D9AC.description: Ask thoughtful questions that probe deeper thought and respond to questions with elaboration.

7BF782A3C61E4BDA9BC21FAE7085BA42.description: Distinguish between verifiable fact and opinion and analyze the message and presentation for evidence.

66AC593A1622474CB0116A7EB0E28133.description: Understand and apply cues and conventions including pragmatic, textual, syntactical, semantic/lexical/morphological, graphophonic, and others to construct and confirm meaning when listening.

F71A91131C0D43BB93FCC2B27B6C9816.description: Select and use pertinent before, during, and after strategies to construct meaning when listening.

A4DB96BC382C4156B153EB4841E53DAB.description: Listen critically and respond appropriately to a range of oral communications including oral traditions passed on by First Nations Elders and Knowledge Keepers.

365282435FE44CC9977AEB244803FFBB.description: Listen, summarize, paraphrase, and evaluate what was heard and draw conclusions.

16F3252C817D44BA9CB054C915C04B20.description: View a multimedia presentation and identify how the language, visual, and multimedia features (e.g., sound, colour, movement) are used to persuade.

92B39D6D6FF64875968E460F513BA24D.description: Understand how a range of visual features (e.g., graphs, images, illustrations, charts, maps, diagrams) can enhance and clarify spoken, written, or silent messages.

67FD504DD89E4F7291DE476D1725B670.description: Identify, with support, the values and aspects of various cultures underlying visual messages including First Nations and Métis art and other texts.

0C27EB758C0849418FA2E59811FE8CEC.description: Identify the intent and appeal of particular TV and print advertisements and other visuals including First Nations and Métis art and other texts.

C03965B973CC47658CF25ED045B0302E.description: Evaluate the role of visuals in focusing attention on particular aspects or events, and influencing opinions on issues.

0E292D3D30274877A3E233E22A1E63C1.description: Understand and apply cues and conventions including pragmatic, textual, syntactical, semantic/lexical/morphological, graphophonic, and others to construct and confirm meaning when viewing.

9F5B50C447254000B0B34EA7BC785A54.description: Select and use pertinent before, during, and after strategies to construct meaning when viewing.

3DA22470C2214130823B69B76A8FEB64.description: Discuss visual experiences (e.g., what was seen and the effectiveness).

E9A4477872864834B198FAB0849F1E10.description: View and respond to visual and multimedia texts (including graphs, charts, diagrams, maps, multimedia DVD, websites, television programs, advertisements, posters), explaining the creator’s technique and the impact on viewers.

6687A533416441428A979A4133E38B51.description: Identify cultural representations in oral, print, and other media texts from various communities including First Nations and Métis communities.

A171954C80FF412C9D46A5A944C6861C.description: Identify similarities and differences between personal experiences and the experiences of people from various cultures portrayed in a variety of texts including First Nations and Métis texts.

30124122A45E4D8FA55BA5D6634B7DFC.description: Connect the insights of an individual or individuals in texts to personal experiences.

1D618E9F82CC42D6A0137F570F694C8B.description: View, listen to, and read a variety of texts related to theme or topic of study and show comprehension by: retelling and explaining the ideas and information presented in texts, recognizing and understanding the text structures (e.g., narrative, informational, poetry) and features (e.g., description, figurative language, graphics) and responding to and interpreting the texts, and explaining and supporting response with evidence from the texts.

A3AF9C782FB34FE19381A7B23434B6B7.description: View, listen to, read, and respond to a variety of texts that reflect diverse personal identities, worldviews, and backgrounds (e.g., culture, age, gender, language) including First Nations and Métis texts

A9FF9F31D3374F2192EF9086D978F0E0.description: Comprehend and respond to a variety of grade-level texts (including contemporary and traditional visual, oral, written, and multimedia texts) that address: identity (e.g., Expressing Myself), community (e.g., Building Community) and social responsibility (e.g., Preserving a Habitat) and support response with evidence from text and from own experiences.

6E8CA5893DD648E98B2B695FB62E9429.description: Comprehend and Respond (CR). Students will develop their abilities to view, listen to, read, comprehend, and respond to a variety of contemporary and traditional grade-level-appropriate texts in a variety of forms (oral, print, and other media) from First Nations, Métis, and other cultures for a variety of purposes including for learning, interest, and enjoyment.
